moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 g6: as I usually do, I develop the Hungarian variation after Nf3; nowadays after Nc3, I prefer d6: I learned that the hard way...
moves.3. Bc4: a very popular move in both the Italian and the Sicilian party: making square f7 a weakness, especially after Ng5; in this Sicilian however, this is a very moot point...
moves.3... Bg7: still following the Hungarian variation: of course, Ng5 will do nothing after e6; the pointe of this variation, also preparing d7-d5 against Bc4...
moves.4. Nc3: dangling between two systems: but all the same, Black has to be prepared for Nb5 or Nd5; hence Blacks' next move...
moves.4... e6: still at risk, in the case of Nb5: the main threat being Nd6+, ruining most of Blacks' plan for setup; safest here is d6 (blocking Nc3-b5-d6), and postpone d7-d5 just a few moves: however, in blitz you do not always have that luxury...
moves.5. d3: way too passive: d4 was a much better option, in challenging Blacks' setup...
moves.5... a6: the old Najdorf addition to the Sicilian party: this will rule out Nb5; and Bb5+ in the case of an early needed d7-d5...
moves.6. a3: for some reason, White wants to challenge the gambit pawn c5: better 0-0 at this point; Black is about to complete the preferred setup...
moves.6... Ne7 7. Be3: right move, wrong time: d7-d5 was imminent; now, square d4 becomes a death trap...
moves.7... d5: a bit of positional luck: in most cases in this stage of this opening, Bb5+ is still a possibility, so Black first needs to castle; a6 shielded that...
moves.8. Bb3: missing the point totally: only after exd5, exd5, Bxc5!, this might work; now it is over...
moves.8... d4: losing a piece, without any compensation: so White resigned; barely 1 minute in the game...
